data.title: Wanted: info on old Unisys boxen
data.text:
Post by Leif Harcke

A while back, I acquired two older Unisys U-series machines: a UN

6031 B and a UN 6051 B.

I think the model numbers were U 6000/31 and U 6000/51. These were

IA-32 architecture PCs running UNIX System Laboratories System V

Release 3. You may try mounting the disk in an old PC, booting into

some flavor of SVR3, and seeing if the OS can find the SCSI disk, list

partitions, and fsck the partitions, etc.

My source said it was server using serial lines to connect the

clients; it came from a retail back-office environment.

The machines were indeed data aggregators for the back-office

environment. Later models were 486 machines running SVR4.

http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3092/is_n4_v31/ai_11875094

[...].

Kmart, while ordering a system to finish its KIN II (Kmart

Information Network II) information system project, has continued to

expand its technology parameters from monitoring and reordering

merchandise into areas that range from in-store laser printing systems

for signs to tracking of store traffic.

The latest KIN II move involves installing the Unisys Intel

486-based U 6000/65 multiprocessor UNIX system--computers, open

system software, peripherals and integrated services--in about 1,200

Kmarts this year. The system will go into another 300 Kmarts opening

during 1993 and 1994.

The U 6000/65 system, which completes the KIN II project, is

custom-configured for Kmart by Unisys. The system runs under UNIX

System Laboratories' UNIX System V Release 4, with multiprocessing

extensions developed by the Multiprocessing Consortium whose members

include Unisys.

KIN II provides personnel with such advanced information processing

capabilities as better product availability and inventory balancing,

extended in-store inventory analysis and labor management. The

result is better customer service and lower costs.

David M. Carlson, vice president, corporate information systems,

said Kmart is migrating to a UNIX standard because it's more flexible,

providing multiuser, multitasking capabilities.

The U 6000/65 system supplements the U 6000 Series computer Kmart

had previously ordered for 1,000 stores. The discounter has already

finished installing over 2,300 other U 6000 Series systems as part of

its receiving department's automation project.

[...]

Yes, I knew some of that. I just can't say

to protect my source. I don't dare let the

things out of my site/sight until the drives

are either wiped or destroyed. But, I like

'mature' machines- I find them fun.

The number scheme- 6051 being

6000/51- is probably what was hindering

my search. I should be able to turn up some

more info now, although first- and second-

hand knowledge is always appreciated.

Thanks,

Tarkin

Anne & Lynn Wheeler

Post by Tarkin

Mainframes sound like a lot of fun

in their own right.

The U-series remains a bit of mystery

to nearly everyone, I'm afraid- except

the fine folks at KMart. Which gives me

a bit of an idea- I just may go to the

source, and see if I can get some info

there, if Usenet doesn't work out.

weren't (at least some of) the u-series the rebranded sequent boxes?

i've seen reference to u-series being unisys 68k unix boxes ... but

weren't the unisys rebranded sequent boxes also labeled as u-series?

of course when IBM bought sequent ... unisys was possibly forced to

adopt some other platform.

sequent did numaq with SCI (scalable coherent interface) ... we did

some consulting to sequent after leaving IBM (and before sequent was

bought by IBM). SCI had 64-port . convex exemplar was 64 boards with

two HP risc processors per board. Sequent (and data general) did SCI

implementation with 64 boards with four intel processor per board (for

256 processor configuration).

later on in this time-frame (before the ibm purchase), Steve Chen

was CTO at sequent. a recent posts mentioning steve chen:
